overview: Students will enrol in the 25‐point offering of this subject in one semester and the 50‐point offering in the second semester to ensure they have completed a total of 75 points for the research project by the end of their course.

Early in the first semester of enrolment, students will formulate a research question / project proposal and present this for approval by the subject coordinator. The second semester concludes with students communicating their research in both oral and written formats ‐ giving a verbal presentation and submitting their thesis.
ilo: Identify, describe and discuss the scientific process including the research methodologies necessary to design and interpret experiments in Human Nutrition
Critically evaluate knowledge gained from a range of scientific sources
Devise controlled studies to enable the collection and interpretation of valid data
Disseminate the method and findings of a research project in Human Nutrition in oral and written form
Effectively analyse, and scientifically evaluate problems and reach appropriate conclusions
generic_skills: The ability to evaluate scientific and professional literature
The ability to use conceptual models to rationalize experimental data
The capacity to articulate their knowledge and understanding in written and oral presentations
The capacity to manage competing demands on time, including self-directed experimental work
The capacity to apply enhanced teamwork skills as required
Respect for integrity in the conduct and reporting of scientific investigations

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: Project proposal - outline of the project
assessment.timing: Four to six weeks from commencement of Semester 1

assessment.brief: Proposal seminar, presentation based on the proposal
assessment.hurdle: satisfactory completion of the proposal seminar
assessment.timing: Four to six weeks from commencement of Semester 1
Two weeks before the end of Semester 2

assessment.brief: Thesis, One written thesis to be submitted for examination
assessment.timing: During the last week of Semester 2

date_times.contact_hours:
Students should discuss total time commitment with their supervisor but as a guide, a student would be expected to be engaged in their research for an average of thirty hours per week over two semesters.



This subject is an individual research project and weekly contact hours will vary depending on the nature of the project.
